p: Bird sensitivity to climate change has been mainly studied during the breeding season. In particular, drastic changes in phenology have been noticed worldwide, triggered by shorter winters in polar and temperate regions [ 9â€“ 11]. Such phenological changes, that differ between species, can lead to a mismatch between food availability and demands for reproduction with strong impacts on breeding success, particularly for migrating species [ 5, 10]. However, the impacts of climatic changes during winter have been the focus of fewer studies [ 6, 12], probably because it is far more challenging to monitor individuals outside the breeding season [ 3].
